svg.title: Hume's Missing Shade of Blue
svg.desc: An interactive visualization of David Hume's missing shade of blue that serves as a counterexample to his claim that all simple ideas are produced from simple impressions

cc:Work.dc:title: Hume's Missing Shade of Blue
cc:Work.dc:source: Hume's A Treatise of Human Nature deadborn from the press in 1739
cc:Work.dc:description: An interactive visualization of David Hume's missing shade of blue that serves as a counterexample to his claim that all simple ideas are produced from simple impressions

rect.desc: A rectangle filled with a gradient going left to right from dark blue to light blue. These represent shades of blue found coloring objects in the world.
rect.title: Shades of Blue from Dark to Light

path.desc: This rectangle represents impressions of shades of blue. It has a blank, a missing shade, indicating that the perceiver has never been visually exposed to that shade of blue.
path.title: Shades of Blue with a Blank

path.desc: For every simple impression there is a corresponding simple idea. The blank indicates that where there is no simple impression there can be no corresponding simple idea. So the perceiver does not (as of yet) have the simple idea of the missing shade of blue.
path.title: Ideas of Shades of Blue with a Blank

g.desc: After the imagination produces the missing shade of blue from scratch and inserts it in its proper place "betwixt the contiguous colours," the set of later simple ideas of shades of blue is complete and has no blank space.
g.title: Later Ideas of Shades of Blue without Blank

path.desc: Hume supposes that the imagination can produce from scratch, without a corresponding impression, a simple idea of a shade of blue.
path.title: Single Shade of Blue from the Imagination

path.desc: The arrow from the imagined shade of blue to the later ideas of shades of blue indicates that the imagination supplies the simple idea of the shade of blue that was missing among the initial ideas.
path.title: Arrow Pointing from Imagined Shade of Blue to Later Ideas

text.desc: Shades of blue color in the world
text.title: Shades of Blue
text.tspan: Blues

text.desc: The impressions of shades of blue are a kind of perception and exist in the perceiver.
text.title: Impressions of Shades of Blue
text.tspan: Impressions

text.desc: Like impressions, simple ideas are perceptions. But they differ from impressions in that they are less lively perceptions that are copies of the impressions.
text.title: Initial Ideas Copied from Impressions
text.tspan: Initial
Ideas
Later
Ideas

text.desc: A shade of blue produced by the imagination.
text.title: An Imagined Shade of Blue
text.tspan: Imagined Shade

path.desc: The arrow from shades of blue to impressions of shades of blue indicates that the shades of blue play a causal role in producing the corresponding impressions.
path.title: Arrow Pointing from Blues to Impressions

path.desc: The arrow indicates that simple ideas are produced from, are copies of, simple impressions.
path.title: Arrow Pointing from Impressions to Initial Ideas

text.desc: Scottish philosopher David Hume (1711-1776) claimed that all simple ideas are produced from simple impressions. In this passage from the Treatise of Human Nature (1.1.1.10), Hume presents an apparent counterexample to this claim. The counterexample is that the simple idea of a single shade of blue color could be produced not by an impression but instead by the imagination.
text.title: Hume's Missing Shade of Blue
text.tspan: David Hume's Missing Shade of Blue

text.desc: The text is from Hume's A Treatise of Human Nature, 1.1.1.10. A similar passage is also in the Enquiry in Section II, Of the Origin of Ideas.
text.title: Attribution
text.tspan: (A Treatise of Human Nature, 1.1.1.10)
There is however one contradictory phaenomenon, which may
prove, that ’tis not absolutely impossible for ideas to go before
their correspondent impressions. I believe it will readily be
allow’d, that the several distinct ideas of colours, which enter
by the eyes, or those of sounds, which are convey’d by the
hearing, are really different from each other, tho’ at the same
time resembling. Now if this be true of different colours, it
must be no less so of the different shades of the same colour,
that each of them produces a distinct idea, independent of the
rest. For if this shou’d be deny’d, ’tis possible, by the continual
gradation of shades, to run a colour insensibly into what is most
remote from it; and if you will not allow any of the means to be
different, you cannot without absurdity deny the extremes to be
the same. Suppose therefore a person to have enjoyed his sight
for thirty years, and to have become perfectly well acquainted
with colours of all kinds, excepting one particular shade of blue,
for instance, which it never has been his fortune to meet with.
Let all the different shades of that colour, except that single one,
be placed before him, descending gradually from the deepest to
the lightest; ’tis plain, that he will perceive a blank, where that
shade is wanting, and will be sensible, that there is a greater
distance in that place betwixt the contiguous colours, than in
any other. Now I ask, whether ’tis possible for him, from his
own imagination, to supply this deficiency, and raise up to
himself the idea of that particular shade, tho’ it had never been
conveyed to him by his senses? I believe there are few but will
be of opinion that he can; and this may serve as a proof, that the
simple ideas are not always derived from the correspondent
impressions; tho’ the instance is so particular and singular, that
’tis scarce worth our observing, and does not merit that for it
alone we should alter our general maxim.

path.desc: The arrow points from a single shade of blue to a block. The block indicates that the shade of blue is prevented from causing a corresponding impression of the shade being produced in the perceiver. The block is thus causally responsible for the blank, the missing shade of blue, among all the successfully produced impressions of shades of blue in the perceiver.
path.title: Arrow from Blue Shade to Block

path.desc: The block indicates that a shade of blue is prevented from causing a corresponding impression of the shade being produced in the perceiver. The block is thus causally responsible for the blank, the missing shade of blue, among all the successfully produced impressions of shades of blue in the perceiver.
path.title: Block Between Arrow and Blank

rect.desc: The black rectangle filled with the blue gradient represents the shades of blue that color the objects which we perceive by sight.
rect.title: Shades of Blue

text.tspan: The black rectangle filled with the blue
gradient represents the shades of blue
that color the objects which we perceive
by sight.

rect.desc: The arrow pointing from blues to impressions indicates that the colors that enter by the eyes (by the sense of sight) play a causal role in producing impressions of the colors. These impressions are a kind of perception in the perceiver.
rect.title: Arrow Pointing from Blues to Impressions

text.tspan: producing impressions of the colors.
The resulting impressions are a kind of
perception in the perceiver; ideas are
another (less lively) kind of perception.
The arrow indicates that the colors that
enter by the eyes play a causal role in

rect.desc: The arrow pointing from a single shade of blue to a block indicates that the shade of blue is prevented (e.g., a person happens never to see an object with that particular shade of blue) from playing its causal role in producing a corresponding idea of the shade of blue.
rect.title: Shade of Blue Blocked

text.tspan: The blocked arrow
indicates that a single
shade of blue is
prevented (e.g., a
person just happens never to see an object
with that particular shade of blue) from
playing its causal role in producing a
corresponding impression of the shade.

rect.desc: The set of impressions of shades of blue. There is a distinct impression for each shade of blue ever perceived by the perceiver. The blank indicates a shade of blue that the perceiver has never seen.
rect.title: Impressions of Shades of Blue with Blank

text.tspan: There is a distinct impression for each
shade ever perceived by the perceiver.
The blank is a placeholder for a shade of
blue that the perceiver has never seen.
This is the set of
impressions of shades of blue.

rect.desc: An impression of the blocked shade of blue fails to be produced and so a blank occupies the place of the missing shade in the perceiver's set of impressions.
rect.title: Blank in Place of Missing Shade of Blue

text.tspan: An impression of the blocked shade of
blue fails to be produced and so a blank
occupies the place of the missing shade
in the perceiver's set of blue impressions.

rect.desc: The arrow pointing from impressions of shades of blue to the initial simple ideas of shades of blue indicates that the ideas are produced from the impressions. For each idea of a shade there is a correspondent impression.
rect.title: Arrow Pointing from Impressions to Initial Ideas

text.tspan: The arrow indicates that the initial ideas
are produced from the impressions. For
each simple idea of a shade there is a
correspondent simple impression.

rect.desc: This is the set of initial simple ideas produced from the set of impressions of shades of blue. There is a one-to-one correspondence between these two sets. So for each idea there is one and only one impression of which the idea is a copy. There is thus no idea for the missing shade of blue because there is no impression of that shade from which the idea could be produced.
rect.title: Initial Ideas of Shades of Blue with Blank

text.tspan: This is the set of initial simple ideas
produced from the set of impressions of
shades of blue. There is a one-to-one
correspondence between these two sets.
So for each idea there is one and only one
impression of which the idea is a copy. There is
thus no idea for the missing shade of blue
because there is no impression of that shade
from which the idea could be produced.

path.desc: This is the (ultimately insufficient) counterexample to the general maxim or claim that all simple ideas arise from simple impressions. Hume supposes it possible that the imagination can create from scratch (i.e., without a corresponding impression) the idea of a single shade of blue, thus supplying for the set of later ideas the previously missing simple idea corresponding to the missing impression of the shade of blue,
path.title: Imagination Creates a Shade of Blue

text.tspan: This is the (ultimately insufficient)
counterexample to the general maxim
or claim that all simple ideas arise from
simple impressions. Hume supposes it
possible that the imagination can create
from scratch (i.e., without a corresponding
impression) the idea of a single shade of
blue, thus supplying the set of later ideas
with the previously
missing simple idea
to be matched to the
missing impression
of the shade of blue,

rect.desc: The set of later simple ideas of shades of blue is complete. The set consists of all the ideas that are copies of impressions of blue as well as of any ideas of shades of blue contributed by the imagination in its efforts to fill any blanks left by the deficiencies of experience.
rect.title: Later Simple Ideas of Shades of Blue

text.tspan: blue is complete. The set consists of all
the ideas that are copies of impressions
of shades of blue as well as of any ideas
of shades added by the imagination in its
efforts to fill in any
blanks left by any
deficiencies in the
perceiver's experience.
The set of later simple ideas of shades of
